headline: Lockheed Martin, Northrop, RTX: Why defense stocks are climbing
summary: Defense stocks, like Northrop Grumman (NOC), Lockheed Martin (LMT), and RTX (RTX), are on the rise after President Trump proposed a plan to raise the US defense spending budget from $1 trillion to $1.5 trillion for 2027. Yahoo Finance Senior Reporter Brooke DiPalma chats with Julie Hyman on Opening Bid to examine the recent stock moves and explain what's next for the defense sector. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Opening Bid.

headline: Boeing, Defense Stocks Rally After Trump Calls for Huge Defense Budget
summary: U.S. defense companies rallied after President Trump called for a $1.5 trillion defense budget, more than $500 billion more than the Pentagon is expected to receive this fiscal year.  Trump said the increased budget was necessary “especially in these very troubled and dangerous times,” in a social-media post late Wednesday.  Shares of Northrop Grumman, Lockheed Martin, L3Harris and RTX jumped between 4% and 8.7%.

Trump said the increased budget was necessary “especially in these very troubled and dangerous times,” in a social-media post late Wednesday.  Shares of Northrop Grumman, Lockheed Martin, L3Harris and RTX jumped between 4% and 8.7%.

headline: Trump's plans for Venezuelan oil, defense spending hikes
summary: President Trump is giving Wall Street investors whiplash with a deluge of new policy proposals, from hiking defense spending to $1.5 trillion to expecting 50 million barrels of Venezuelan oil (CL=F, BZ=F) and plans to ban institutional investors from buying single-family homes. Yahoo Finance Washington correspondent Ben Werschkul comes on the program to explain Trump's vision for the US occupation of Venezuela in relation to the oil industry, while the administration seeks to raise its defense budget in 2027. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Morning Brief.

headline: Defense Stocks Jump After Trump Calls for $1.5 Trillion Defense Budget
summary: U.S. defense companies rallied premarket after President Trump called for a $1.5 trillion defense budget, more than $500 billion more than the Pentagon is expected to receive this fiscal year.  Trump said the increased budget was necessary “especially in these very troubled and dangerous times,” in a social-media post late Wednesday.  Shares of Northrop Grumman, Lockheed Martin, and RTX each jumped 4.5% or more in premarket trading.

raw.headline: Defense Stocks Jump After Trump Calls for $1.5 Trillion Defense Budget

Trump said the increased budget was necessary “especially in these very troubled and dangerous times,” in a social-media post late Wednesday.  Shares of Northrop Grumman, Lockheed Martin, and RTX each jumped 4.5% or more in premarket trading.

headline: Trump Demands More Defense Spending But Threatens Biggest Contractors
summary: The apparently contradictory string of announcements sent shares of major defense contractors tumbling as traders sought to interpret the White House’s intentions — and whether they would ever come to pass.  It all began with a demand that hit on a long-time issue for Trump: Major defense contractors that work with the government must end stock buybacks, stop issuing dividends and cap executive pay at $5 million a year until they invest more in factories and research to speed development.  Hours later, Trump signed an executive order codifying the decision.

raw.headline: Trump Demands More Defense Spending But Threatens Biggest Contractors
raw.summary: The apparently contradictory string of announcements sent shares of major defense contractors tumbling as traders sought to interpret the White House’s intentions — and whether they would ever come to pass.  It all began with a demand that hit on a long-time issue for Trump: Major defense contractors that work with the government must end stock buybacks, stop issuing dividends and cap executive pay at $5 million a year until they invest more in factories and research to speed development.  Hours later, Trump signed an executive order codifying the decision.
